text:
Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion,

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this is not even a question that should be asked.  Of course schools should be providing free pads and tampons to students.  

I should point out, right from the beginning, that I have never experienced period shaming or period poverty.  As you might have guessed, I am a member of the other half of the population, that will literally never have this experience.  However, as a member of the human race, I feel it is necessary to look out for the needs of those who do.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this is not even a question that should be asked.  Of course schools should be providing free pads and tampons to students.  

I should point out, right from the beginning, that I have never experienced period shaming or period poverty.  As you might have guessed, I am a member of the other half of the population, that will literally never have this experience.  However, as a member of the human race, I feel it is necessary to look out for the needs of those who do.

Currently, in the United States, although Title 10, Section 5131.6 of Law states that public schools should provide menstrual and breast-feeding supplies to students.  So it is already a matter of law.  Since laws can be changed, however, I hope to convince you that these programs should not be cut.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, this is not even a question that should be asked.  Of course schools should be providing free pads and tampons to students.  

I should point out, right from the beginning, that I have never experienced period shaming or period poverty.  As you might have guessed, I am a member of the other half of the population, that will literally never have this experience.  However, as a member of the human race, I feel it is necessary to look out for the needs of those who do.

Currently, in the United States, although Title 10, Section 5131.6 of Law states that public schools should provide menstrual and breast-feeding supplies to students.  So it is already a matter of law.  Since laws can be changed, however, I hope to convince you that these programs should not be cut.

Before I continue, I would like to talk about toilet paper for a moment.  Imagine if you had to rush to the restrooms between classes, and once you were finished, you realized that there was no toilet paper in your stall.  You politely ask the person next to you to pass some under the walls, but he or she refuses.  This other person tells you that you should have planned ahead, and, besides, your bodily functions are disgusting and you should not be talking about them.  Does this sound far-fetched to you?  It should, because no one would behave like that other person.

And yet this is what women and girls are subjected to on a daily basis when it comes to their periods.

Currently, in the United States, although Title 10, Section 5131.6 of Law states that public schools should provide menstrual and breast-feeding supplies to students.  So it is already a matter of law.  Since laws can be changed, however, I hope to convince you that these programs should not be cut.

Before I continue, I would like to talk about toilet paper for a moment.  Imagine if you had to rush to the restrooms between classes, and once you were finished, you realized that there was no toilet paper in your stall.  You politely ask the person next to you to pass some under the walls, but he or she refuses.  This other person tells you that you should have planned ahead, and, besides, your bodily functions are disgusting and you should not be talking about them.  Does this sound far-fetched to you?  It should, because no one would behave like that other person.

And yet this is what women and girls are subjected to on a daily basis when it comes to their periods.  They are mocked and shamed for their natural, healthy biological function.  And if they can't afford the necessary sanitary supplies, or simply can't afford them, many people have no problem in blaming the victim.  We say that she should have planned ahead, or should have been more responsible.  This is simply unacceptable.  Schools should be prepared to help these students because it is the right thing to do, and also, because students will not be able to learn otherwise.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

---

I should point out, right from the beginning, that I have never experienced period shaming or period poverty.  As you might have guessed, I am a member of the other half of the population, that will literally never have this experience.  However, as a member of the human race, I feel it is necessary to look out for the needs of those who do.

Currently, in the United States, although Title 10, Section 5131.6 of Law states that public schools should provide menstrual and breast-feeding supplies to students.  So it is already a matter of law.  Since laws can be changed, however, I hope to convince you that these programs should not be cut.

Before I continue, I would like to talk about toilet paper for a moment.  Imagine if you had to rush to the restrooms between classes, and once you were finished, you realized that there was no toilet paper in your stall.  You politely ask the person next to you to pass some under the walls, but he or she refuses.  This other person tells you that you should have planned ahead, and, besides, your bodily functions are disgusting and you should not be talking about them.  Does this sound far-fetched to you?  It should, because no one would behave like that other person.

And yet this is what women and girls are subjected to on a daily basis when it comes to their periods.  They are mocked and shamed for their natural, healthy biological function.  And if they can't afford the necessary sanitary supplies, or simply can't afford them, many people have no problem in blaming the victim.  We say that she should have planned ahead, or should have been more responsible.  This is simply unacceptable.  Schools should be prepared to help these students because it is the right thing to do, and also, because students will not be able to learn otherwise.

Besides, if the schools already have free toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids, etc. then they should also have free pads and tampons.  All of us are equal, and all lives matter (as some opponents of my viewpoint are eager to point out), so we all deserve some basic accommodations.  Toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids are all necessary to our health.  They are not free, yet we never think twice about providing them in public to those who are in need, because health and sanitation are important and necessary for everyone.  

Reproductive health should be treated the same as any other public-health issue.

Toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids are all necessary to our health.  They are not free, yet we never think twice about providing them in public to those who are in need, because health and sanitation are important and necessary for everyone.  Reproductive health should be treated the same as any other public-health issue.  If toilet paper is necessary for every student and public-health issue, then so are pads and tampons.  

If you have some objection to the cost of these supplies, just ask yourself if you would be willing to give up free toilet paper, soap, and Band-Aids in public.  If it's not acceptable when it happens to you, then it's not acceptable when it happens to anyone.

And that is, literally, all there is to say.
